    As such times requested have had to be considerably reduced when I fix the "guillotine" times to the heads of expenditure under Standing Order 89(7)(a). I would like to remind hon. Members that the times for discussion of the heads of expenditure include the replies from the front bench. I would therefore urge Members to be brief and succinct when raising their points so that we can meet the "guillotine" times. The front bench too can assist in this by not giving overly long statements and replies.

Column: 1100



    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head U -

    The Chairman: Head U - Prime Minister's Office. Amendment No. (1), Mr Inderjit Singh.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head U of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, now, more than ever, the issue of racial harmony is something we have to spend a lot of time addressing. The events after September 11 triggered greater awareness of the type of problems racial and religious differences can cause. In Singapore, we saw signs of problems starting with the reactions to the September 11 issues and then followed by the tudung issue. Looking back a few years ago, we also saw glimpses of racial issues when hiring practices of certain type of employers were openly discussed here. While most Singaporeans behaved rationally through all the periods I mentioned, at the ground level there were quite a few who felt otherwise and raised suspicions about the other races. The levels of these suspicions are still not widespread and are not a cause of major concern yet. It nonetheless highlights how delicate the situation can be and therefore we cannot take things for granted.

    As a nation, we have made progress in many areas, including inter-racial ties. When I was growing up in the 1960s and 1970s, most of us were not so conscious of our races and we grew up thinking of each other as more or less the same. The changes which happened in the 1980s as a result of certain policies and practices started causing the realisation of our differences and thus resulting in some weaknesses in the race relations' foundations which we are still building. Some of these policies and practices causing the problems are: first, creating the ethnic based self-help groups where each feels that only their own kind will help them; second, high profile campaigns like the Speak Mandarin Campaigns which are all

Column: 1101

right on their own, but which were not very well explained in the early years leading to suspicions of the intent of such a campaign; third, school practices of segregating children by the language streams that they came from in the past. While this is less of a problem now, it was a problem before; fourth, the creation of SAP schools which again is all right for the intended purpose, but other races never fully understood the need for them; fifth, putting emphasis on mother tongue and using it as a means of grading and measuring children's abilities to move forward in education causing our children to focus a lot on their mother tongue and also emphasis on them interacting with each other so that they could practise the language.

    While policies are important, it is equally important that our people interact with each other in schools and in their daily lives to build up bonds. Today, we and especially our children do not have enough opportunities to interact with each other. Even when they go to our secular schools, they tend to largely congregate along racial lines. The long term trend can be detrimental and unless our race relations have sufficient depth and can withstand any stresses, we will have serious problems should any racial problems arise. We should not be complacent because the level of race issues and stresses we have seen is small and our laws could contain any potential problem. My opinion is that should we see any high levels of stresses, the seemingly good racial ties here may not necessarily remain good.

    We therefore need to do more to ensure that our people are really close to each other and go from beyond tolerance and understanding to fully accepting each other and adapting to each other's way of life. Each of us has to make personal changes. We cannot live in a cocoon and think that a particular race's problem is not our own personal problem because we are all living in the same neighbourhood and any problems in the neighbourhood will inevitably affect all of us. I would like to suggest three initiatives that will help us deepen racial ties.

Column: 1102



    First of all, organising self-help groups along ethnic lines. I believe it is about time that we broke this into two components. The first component basically consists of administrative fund raising and coordination issues. This could make up of people from all ethnic races. The second component should be the component that actually reaches out to the various ethnic groups. Because that has been very effective, the ethnic group approach of reaching out to people has been the right thing to do. By organising the way we are organising right now ---

    The Chairman: Mr Inderjit Singh, I think you need to be short. Please get to the point.

    Mr Inderjit Singh: Okay. The smaller ethnic groups actually have problems raising funds. When we organise ourselves along the suggestion I am making, it will help them to lessen the problem. The second problem is that our SAP school children and Madrasah children do not have the opportunities to interact with children of other races. So I would like to suggest that schools implement a twinning concept where SAP schools and Madrasahs are twinned with secular schools so that, during academic time, the children can spend time in the various schools. But when they participate in CCA and ECA activities, the children from the SAP or Madrasah schools should do it jointly with the students from the twinned secular schools and, in this way, they will have an opportunity to interact almost on a daily basis. If they grow up doing this, they will get to understand each other even better.

    Finally, I fully support the implementation of the IRCC. I see it as an equaliser of races. It does not matter how big the size of the ethnic group is. Everyone should be equally represented in this group. And I hope that the Minister will consider funding this group sufficiently so that they can do a lot more than just being coordinating agencies.

    The Chairman: You have taken five minutes, Mr Inderjit Singh.

Column: 1103



    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to support Mr Inderjit's call and call for more multi-racial approach to solving this country's challenges. One of the major challenges that we have is to reach out and provide help to children from poor families so that they will not be caught in the poverty trap. This calls for a national effort. Right now, this role is carried out mostly by ethnic-based self-help groups. Each of these groups has done very good work. But some, such as the CDCs and CDAC, have more resources than others. This is in terms of funding and volunteer base. This means that those with less resources, such as SINDA and the Eurasian Association, may be handicapped in their mission. Moreover, not all have the same access to management expertise.

    Over the years, we also see a growing number of Singaporeans of the different races volunteering to serve in these groups and they come from all races - the Chinese serving at SINDA and MENDAKI, the Malay serving at CDAC, and so on and so forth. This is a healthy sign and it shows that Singaporeans do want a multi-racial approach. It would make sense for one multi-racial body as the managing agent overseeing such services and tapping from a wide pool of volunteers and funds, rather than the different ethnic-based groups tapping from their own narrow base. If I have a Malay resident coming to me seeking for help, I would not have to refer him to MENDAKI, but to this multi-racial body. This way, poor students from the different races will then also be able to attend the same classes together and they will not be segregated. It will also send the right signals so crucial in these times. That you do not have to depend on your own kind to help you when you need the help. This is the time for us to foster this confidence and not wait until a race riot occurs for us to find out that we cannot depend on the other.

    Let us, at this time, push forward this multi-racial agenda.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, the September 11 incident has given us an

Column: 1104

occasion to examine our multi-racial policy. After 35 years of independence, we have to ask ourselves whether we want our society to continue in its plural form where the State continues to accept and work with the various ethnic groups or do we want to allow society to evolve naturally with the effluxion of time so that, with it, we have a common cultural identity emerging that is characterised to a large extent by cross cultural influences.

    Sir, this point may well be illustrated by looking at the American society. We all know that the United States is characterised largely by a society that is made up of migrant people, it is cosmopolitan in nature. But, however, if you look at the third and fourth generations, it would be very difficult for them to continue with their cultural practices and native language. Many American-born Chinese, for example, grow up in the US without speaking the Chinese language properly. And yet, in America, you find that there is an emerging distinct identity of Americans who see themselves as a new American that is divorced almost entirely from their ethnic origins. This is the kind of new American that has created a separate and distinct identity that the world can identify with.

    Now, we may well ask whether the United States' model has any relevance for us here. I would say yes, when you look at it from the perspective of community bonding. Sir, by community bonding, one would suppose a sense of feeling as one, united by a common cultural experience and founded in a common language. The Singapore model, for want of a better word, arguably works towards the reinforcement of different cultural identities. In our official media, for example, we pay formal recognition to the four major languages that we identify as official. In many public functions that are organised by State agencies and community based organisations, the organisers are required to pay the obligatory lip service by ensuring that the dances of the four major ethnic groups are represented. I am quite sure that this phenomenon takes place across the island. While pursuing this separate and distinct

Column: 1105

cultural identity to a fault, the question that we have to ask is whether such policies will help to promote and reinforce community bonding here. My suspicion is that it does not.

    Far from witnessing more cross-cultural exchanges, my own observation and experience is that ethnic groups are becoming more insular and inward-looking in their daily lives. Is it any wonder that when RCs organise educational visits, it is mainly the Chinese who attend these tours, perhaps because temple visits are a part of the itinerary? Is it any wonder also that Malays also prefer the comfort of interacting within the extended family and the confines of the mosques? And is it any wonder that most CCs often find it difficult to have more members for the IAECs because there are not enough of such volunteers around?

    Sir, the retreat to their comfort zones is no doubt spurred on by the greater familiarity of the respective languages. Unless such tendencies are checked, it would be difficult indeed to see how greater community bonding across races can be achieved.

    Sir, society and cultural values and practices have a way of evolving naturally that is not necessarily defined by the state. I believe that any body of people would, over time, produce a set of shared values and practices that forms the basis of the group's identity that need not be determined extraneously. In our case, we could perhaps use proper Singapore English as a basis for the new Singaporean identity that transcends all individual cultural barriers.

    Sir, if we accept this suggestion as the way forward, we have to fundamentally redefine the way in which our Government takes the initiative in preserving our cultural heritage. For instance, the Speak Mandarin Campaign should be left entirely to the community groups to promote. Secondly, the various community self-help organisations, as my two colleagues had advocated eloquently

Column: 1106

earlier, should be reorganised into one large self-help organisation that is independent of race, language or religion. The Government, on the other hand, could well just allow and focus on the natural development of the proper Singapore English. Over time, it is hoped that a common language will be the social glue that binds the people together and, over time, it is hoped that our people should not feel that they have lost their cultural heritage simply because they do not speak the language. What matters most, as I have said earlier, is that they must feel that they are still who they are ethnically and yet, at the same time, be bonded by a stronger common identity which they feel in common with those of the other ethnic groups.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): The MPs have raised points on an important subject. Our philosophy has always been to promote social integration and a common national identity among Singaporeans while ensuring that each community can retain its own cultural identity and heritage. So, we facilitated ways for Singaporeans to live, learn and socialise in an integrated environment. We have key policies in education, public housing and People's Association programmes as examples which help to maintain the common space where Singaporeans can interact with other races.

    But, at the same time, we cannot force the pace beyond what people are comfortable with, otherwise it will be counter-productive, because each community wants to retain its own identity and to have its own space where members can interact with one another, as Mr Sin Boon Ann says, their comfort zone. And we must also recognise that the tendency for different groups to segregate will always be present because of different customs and religious requirements. And heightened religious consciousness, strict observance of rules of diet, dress, conduct, particularly among Muslims, have accentuated this tendency to separateness.

Column: 1107



    In the present situation, we need to make greater efforts to strengthen inter-racial ties, especially among the leaders of the different communities, so that we can deal with any problems which may arise. And we are actively doing this through IRCCs and via activities in the community centres to reach out and bring together Singaporeans of different races.

    Self-help groups are not the root cause of ethnic consciousness or of the distance between the different communities. They were set up for a specific purpose, ie, to help the under-achievers in each community to overcome their problems and uplift themselves, especially educationally, in a way which a multi-racial group will find difficult to do. In this respect, the self-help groups have done well and will continue to play a role.

    At the same time, the self-help groups do encourage their respective communities to interact more with other communities. Often, they have volunteers from other communities and they collaborate to organise activities at festivals such as Deepavali, Christmas, Hari Raya Puasa or Chinese New Year. These events help bring Singaporeans together from different ethnic groups and better understand and appreciate each other's values and customs.

    But looking ahead, the self-help groups can do more to work closely in partnership with one another. As the Prime Minister suggested last week, they should partner other groups and agencies to run tuition and other programmes, rather than duplicate services. For example, the self-help groups are planning to organise and run a joint service centre in Toa Payoh with an integrated management and staff, and cooperating with the CDC and, if this works, we will be able to do it in other towns as well. This partnership approach will prevent us from swinging unwittingly to the undesirable extreme which the MPs have highlighted, where more and more social services and programmes are provided along ethnic lines. It will also enable us to pool resources,

Column: 1108

minimise duplication and address Mr Inderjit Singh's concern that the small self-help groups may be disadvantaged because of their limited access to funds and resources.

    Mr Inderjit Singh also spoke about the need for regular interaction of our school children with other races and suggested twinning of schools where students can do their co-curricular activities or extra-curricular activities together. It is an idea which is worth exploring. I understand that MUIS, the Madrasahs and our schools are actively looking on programmes to enable their students to interact with other races and appreciate the national perspective. The Ministry of Education and MCDS will study to see how we can promote this further.

    Mr Inderjit Singh also suggested that the IRCCs be given a budget to tap on for their activities to promote racial interaction. The IRCC is really an extension of the Citizens Consultative Committee. It is not meant to be another formalised and structured or activity-centric grassroots committee. For a start, to better understand ground conditions and build rapport with the relevant local establishments, many IRCCs have visited religious institutions like temples, mosques, churches and so on.

    For the next phase, they could initiate informal dialogue and chit-chat sessions with local groups to identify pressing areas and practical opportunities for building inter-ethnic understanding. Both the CDCs and the CCCs can finance these efforts and the People's Association will seek the concurrence of the Grassroots Grants Committee to increase the allocation of grassroots grants to the CCCs for activities promoting racial harmony.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, the continual injection of talents into the civil service is crucial to maintaining a vibrant and dynamic service. However, the size of the civil service is capped to ensure that it is not bloated. My colleague, Mr Inderjit Singh, even called for it to be scaled down by 30%. Moreover, when a young officer is recruited at an age fresh out of university,

Column: 1109

he has a 30-year working life in the service. With all the scholars we have recruited in the service all these years, it is possible that we have reached a point where the annual intake of scholars far outnumbers those retiring officers based on natural attrition. Furthermore, the terms of service are also so attractive that few would leave the comfort zone to strike out on their own.

    Sir, in many cases, those who are good in academic studies make better researchers and academicians than Division 1 officers. To my mind, Sir, it would be better for the Government to recruit those with proven abilities from the market and to depend less on the scholars. This is especially so for those in the elite Administrative Service. As regards the scholars that we have already signed on, it might be better to assign them to the private sector, such as those in the GLCs, to test them out first. I understand that there is a programme to attract mid-career officers, but the outcome to date has been quite poor. May I know what are the reasons? Would the Government review the mid-career options and renew the emphasis on this? I believe, with the current recession, it would be a good time to tap the market for mid-career officers.

    The Chairman: Mr Zainul Abidin is not here. Mr Steve Chia.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, currently the scholarship bond is strict and non-convertible. Our best and brightest students are sent over to the best universities overseas to learn and mix with the world's best and brightest. Then, they are asked to come back and serve in the public service or the Armed Forces with a fast-track career. This may have served the public administration, the Armed Forces and the statutory boards well in the past and the present. But the time has come for us to expand the system a little bit further.

    It is no longer enough to send out brightest students to these prestigious schools for four years and then get them

Column: 1110

to come back to serve. Will the Government consider allowing some of these scholars, those who are interested and able, to secure careers on their own with the top 500 Fortune companies, to allow them to postpone serving their bonds for a period of time? Let them gain work experience in these top MNCs, learn their system, adopt their work cultures and benefit by dealing with the companies' best and brightest. After five to 10 years, when these scholars are prepared to come back to Singapore, they may be invited back to serve Singapore in any of the sectors or industries, public or private. If they do not intend to come to Singapore at all, then we can exercise the contractual bond and demand high compensation for breaking the contract. This will be our best form of international talent that we can develop and groom and call our own. We can be proud if a few of our top scholars are groomed to climb the corporate ladders in these top MNCs and then come back to serve their duty in Singapore, in one of the SMEs or the GLCs.

    I believe the details and technicalities can be worked out if this idea is considered. I hope the Ministry can take some of these initiatives to prepare Singapore for long-term competitiveness. I hope the Prime Minister can look further and explore the feasibility of this proposal.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong: Sir, the Government is an enlightened and exemplary employer in all aspects, except when it comes to the medical benefits scheme for civil servants. Under this scheme, family members of a female civil servant are not entitled to medical benefits in the same way as those of their male counterparts.

    Sir, tell me how I can explain to the women, such as our SAF women regulars and our many top women civil servants, that this is a patriarchal society, so just accept it? Women have made great strides over the years. We have a woman commanding officer in the artillery, and a woman captain of a ship in the Navy. If you are on a ship going to battle, it does not matter if you are a man or a woman. You are on the same battleship going to

Column: 1111

war, defending your country. The risk is the same. The rewards, too, must be equal.

    Yesterday, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong told us about the new Medisave scheme for civil servants. They have $350 worth of outpatient allowance that the men can use for their children but the women cannot. At the end of the year, the unused balance goes into their Medisave, which can be used to pay for their dependants' medical treatment. So, Deputy Prime Minister Lee said it is essentially the same. But it is not the same. The distinction found in the old scheme is still found in the new scheme. The men can use the $350 worth of outpatient allowance for their dependants and the women cannot. In dollar terms, the distinction may be very small but, in symbolic terms, nothing has changed. It is still unequal benefits for equal work. It is still unfair.
